title: How to Make Eggs Italiano

steps.headline: Fill a dutch oven with some water.
steps.description: You can substitute a large, straight-sided skillet as a substitute for a Dutch oven. In either case, fill the receptacle with approximately 2" (5 cm) of water. Bring this to a boil, then add ¼ cup (59.1 ml) of white vinegar to it. When choosing an appropriate skillet, choose one that is deep enough to accommodate all your ingredients. A saute pan will likely be too shallow.

steps.headline: Cook the shallot and garlic in a separate skillet.
steps.description: While the water in your dutch oven/straight-sided skillet is heating, insert your shallot and garlic into a large, nonstick skillet. Cook this for about one minute over medium-high heat, stirring regularly. Depending on circumstances, these ingredients may take less time to cook. Generally, you can tell when they're done when emit a strong, fragrant smell.

steps.headline: Insert zucchini and tomatoes to the shallot and garlic mix.
steps.description: Use a wooden spoon or similar kitchen utensil to stir in the zucchini and tomatoes. Allow this to cook until the zucchini is tender. This should take about 10 minutes. Stir the mixture occasionally while it cooks.

steps.headline: Remove the skillet from the heat and add seasonings to it.
steps.description: When this mixture is finished cooking, remove the skillet from the heat and stir in your seasonings. These include the basil, balsamic vinegar, salt, and a few twists of pepper.

steps.headline: Cook your eggs.
steps.description: At this point, the water in your other dutch oven/skillet should be boiling. Reduce the heat so the water is at a simmer, with steam rising from it along with small bubbles. Crack each egg into a bowl, then gently transfer the egg to the simmering water. For this recipe to turn out as intended, the egg of each yolk should be unbroken.

steps.headline: Transfer the eggs to a clean towel when they finish cooking.
steps.description: Allow the eggs to cook for 4 minutes if you want them to be soft, 5 minutes for medium, and 8 minutes for hard. Use a slotted spoon to fish out the eggs. Allow the eggs to dry on a clean kitchen towel or paper towel. Be careful when transferring eggs from your skillet to your kitchen towel or paper towel. The yolks of the eggs should remain unbroken.

steps.headline: Serve the ingredients on toasted halves of English muffin.
steps.description: Lay your toasted halves of muffin on a serving plate. Use a wooden spoon or similar utensil to layer the veggie mix on the muffin. Top the veggie mix with your cooked eggs, and enjoy. For a little extra taste and improved presentation, sprinkle a little bit of cheese and finely cut basil on top the eggs.

methods.name: Preparing Eggs Italiano in Red Sauce

steps.headline: Combine tomatoes, salt, pepper, red pepper, and oregano.
steps.description: When adding your tomatoes to your skillet, be sure to include the tomato juice, too. Then add the salt, pepper, red pepper flakes, and oregano to the mix. Heat it over medium-high heat until it begins to bubble. Use a wooden spoon or a similar utensil to stir these ingredients so that the mixture is consistent throughout.

steps.headline: Crack the eggs into small wells made in the tomatoes.
steps.description: With your spoon, separate the tomatoes to make shallow wells in the mixture. Crack the egg into the well. There should be enough liquid in the mixture so that the eggs are submerged. Be careful when cracking your eggs. To properly prepare this dish, the yolks of the eggs should be unbroken.

steps.headline: Cook the eggs until they have solidified, yet are still runny.
steps.description: This should take between 7 and 10 minutes. For softer eggs, cook for approximately 7 minutes. For medium eggs, cook for 8½ minutes, and for hard eggs cook for 10 minutes. Depending on your cooktop, the heat may be uneven. If the is the case for you, you may need to adjust the position of the skillet while cooking so the eggs heat evenly.

steps.headline: Add olive oil, pepper, Parmesan cheese, and parsley.
steps.description: When the eggs have reached your desired consistency, remove them from the heat. Drizzle the olive oil over the eggs. Then sprinkle them with pepper, Parmesan, and parsley.

steps.headline: Serve the eggs and enjoy.
steps.description: With a large serving spoon, scoop the eggs and the sauce onto serving plates. This dish goes well with toast or a firm kind of bread. Dip the bread into the egg yolk and use it to soak up the sauce.

steps.headline: Warm your olive oil in your skillet.
steps.description: Place your large skillet onto the stovetop and set it to medium heat. Allow this to heat until the pan and oil are hot. This should take only a few minutes.

steps.headline: Combine your eggs, basil, and cheese.
steps.description: Crack your eggs into a mixing bowl. Then add your basil and cheese to the eggs. Use a whisk or fork to beat these ingredients together. You can easily add to this recipe to make double portion by simply doubling these ingredients.

steps.headline: Scramble your eggs in the skillet.
steps.description: Add the eggs to your skillet. Use your spatula to push the eggs around so they cook evenly. It should only take a few minutes for the eggs to solidify and cook completely. You shouldn't need to adjust your heat at any point in the scrambling process. Leaving it at medium should cook your eggs sufficiently.

steps.headline: Eat your eggs on garlic bread.
steps.description: Garlic bread is only a recommendation; these eggs could also be eaten on toast, on peasant bread, or on their own. Regular bread can be transformed into garlic bread by brushing it with butter and minced garlic.

text: Cooking Eggs Italiano Fill a dutch oven with some water. You can substitute a large, straight-sided skillet as a substitute for a Dutch oven. In either case, fill the receptacle with approximately 2" (5 cm) of water. Bring this to a boil, then add ¼ cup (59.1 ml) of white vinegar to it. When choosing an appropriate skillet, choose one that is deep enough to accommodate all your ingredients. A saute pan will likely be too shallow. Cook the shallot and garlic in a separate skillet. While the water in your dutch oven/straight-sided skillet is heating, insert your shallot and garlic into a large, nonstick skillet. Cook this for about one minute over medium-high heat, stirring regularly. Depending on circumstances, these ingredients may take less time to cook. Generally, you can tell when they're done when emit a strong, fragrant smell. Insert zucchini and tomatoes to the shallot and garlic mix. Use a wooden spoon or similar kitchen utensil to stir in the zucchini and tomatoes. Allow this to cook until the zucchini is tender. This should take about 10 minutes. Stir the mixture occasionally while it cooks. Remove the skillet from the heat and add seasonings to it. When this mixture is finished cooking, remove the skillet from the heat and stir in your seasonings. These include the basil, balsamic vinegar, salt, and a few twists of pepper. Cook your eggs. At this point, the water in your other dutch oven/skillet should be boiling. Reduce the heat so the water is at a simmer, with steam rising from it along with small bubbles. Crack each egg into a bowl, then gently transfer the egg to the simmering water. For this recipe to turn out as intended, the egg of each yolk should be unbroken. Transfer the eggs to a clean towel when they finish cooking. Allow the eggs to cook for 4 minutes if you want them to be soft, 5 minutes for medium, and 8 minutes for hard. Use a slotted spoon to fish out the eggs. Allow the eggs to dry on a clean kitchen towel or paper towel. Be careful when transferring eggs from your skillet to your kitchen towel or paper towel. The yolks of the eggs should remain unbroken. Serve the ingredients on toasted halves of English muffin. Lay your toasted halves of muffin on a serving plate. Use a wooden spoon or similar utensil to layer the veggie mix on the muffin. Top the veggie mix with your cooked eggs, and enjoy. For a little extra taste and improved presentation, sprinkle a little bit of cheese and finely cut basil on top the eggs. Preparing Eggs Italiano in Red Sauce Combine tomatoes, salt, pepper, red pepper, and oregano. When adding your tomatoes to your skillet, be sure to include the tomato juice, too. Then add the salt, pepper, red pepper flakes, and oregano to the mix. Heat it over medium-high heat until it begins to bubble. Use a wooden spoon or a similar utensil to stir these ingredients so that the mixture is consistent throughout. Crack the eggs into small wells made in the tomatoes. With your spoon, separate the tomatoes to make shallow wells in the mixture. Crack the egg into the well. There should be enough liquid in the mixture so that the eggs are submerged. Be careful when cracking your eggs. To properly prepare this dish, the yolks of the eggs should be unbroken. Cook the eggs until they have solidified, yet are still runny. This should take between 7 and 10 minutes. For softer eggs, cook for approximately 7 minutes. For medium eggs, cook for 8½ minutes, and for hard eggs cook for 10 minutes. Depending on your cooktop, the heat may be uneven. If the is the case for you, you may need to adjust the position of the skillet while cooking so the eggs heat evenly. Add olive oil, pepper, Parmesan cheese, and parsley. When the eggs have reached your desired consistency, remove them from the heat. Drizzle the olive oil over the eggs. Then sprinkle them with pepper, Parmesan, and parsley. Serve the eggs and enjoy. With a large serving spoon, scoop the eggs and the sauce onto serving plates. This dish goes well with toast or a firm kind of bread. Dip the bread into the egg yolk and use it to soak up the sauce. Frying up Scrambled Eggs Italiano Warm your olive oil in your skillet. Place your large skillet onto the stovetop and set it to medium heat. Allow this to heat until the pan and oil are hot. This should take only a few minutes. Combine your eggs, basil, and cheese. Crack your eggs into a mixing bowl. Then add your basil and cheese to the eggs. Use a whisk or fork to beat these ingredients together. You can easily add to this recipe to make double portion by simply doubling these ingredients. Scramble your eggs in the skillet. Add the eggs to your skillet. Use your spatula to push the eggs around so they cook evenly. It should only take a few minutes for the eggs to solidify and cook completely. You shouldn't need to adjust your heat at any point in the scrambling process. Leaving it at medium should cook your eggs sufficiently. Eat your eggs on garlic bread. Garlic bread is only a recommendation; these eggs could also be eaten on toast, on peasant bread, or on their own. Regular bread can be transformed into garlic bread by brushing it with butter and minced garlic. Finished.

You can substitute a large, straight-sided skillet as a substitute for a Dutch oven.
In either case, fill the receptacle with approximately 2" (5 cm) of water.
Bring this to a boil, then add ¼ cup (59.1 ml) of white vinegar to it.
When choosing an appropriate skillet, choose one that is deep enough to accommodate all your ingredients.
A saute pan will likely be too shallow.
Cook the shallot and garlic in a separate skillet.
While the water in your dutch oven/straight-sided skillet is heating, insert your shallot and garlic into a large, nonstick skillet.
Cook this for about one minute over medium-high heat, stirring regularly.
Depending on circumstances, these ingredients may take less time to cook.
Generally, you can tell when they're done when emit a strong, fragrant smell.
Insert zucchini and tomatoes to the shallot and garlic mix.
Use a wooden spoon or similar kitchen utensil to stir in the zucchini and tomatoes.
Allow this to cook until the zucchini is tender.
This should take about 10 minutes.
Stir the mixture occasionally while it cooks.

When this mixture is finished cooking, remove the skillet from the heat and stir in your seasonings.
These include the basil, balsamic vinegar, salt, and a few twists of pepper.
Cook your eggs.
At this point, the water in your other dutch oven/skillet should be boiling.
Reduce the heat so the water is at a simmer, with steam rising from it along with small bubbles.
Crack each egg into a bowl, then gently transfer the egg to the simmering water.
For this recipe to turn out as intended, the egg of each yolk should be unbroken.
Transfer the eggs to a clean towel when they finish cooking.
Allow the eggs to cook for 4 minutes if you want them to be soft, 5 minutes for medium, and 8 minutes for hard.
Use a slotted spoon to fish out the eggs.
Allow the eggs to dry on a clean kitchen towel or paper towel.
Be careful when transferring eggs from your skillet to your kitchen towel or paper towel.
The yolks of the eggs should remain unbroken.
Serve the ingredients on toasted halves of English muffin.
Lay your toasted halves of muffin on a serving plate.
Use a wooden spoon or similar utensil to layer the veggie mix on the muffin.
Top the veggie mix with your cooked eggs, and enjoy.
For a little extra taste and improved presentation, sprinkle a little bit of cheese and finely cut basil on top the eggs.
Preparing Eggs Italiano in Red Sauce Combine tomatoes, salt, pepper, red pepper, and oregano.
When adding your tomatoes to your skillet, be sure to include the tomato juice, too.
Then add the salt, pepper, red pepper flakes, and oregano to the mix.
Heat it over medium-high heat until it begins to bubble.
Use a wooden spoon or a similar utensil to stir these ingredients so that the mixture is consistent throughout.
Crack the eggs into small wells made in the tomatoes.
With your spoon, separate the tomatoes to make shallow wells in the mixture.
Crack the egg into the well.
There should be enough liquid in the mixture so that the eggs are submerged.
Be careful when cracking your eggs.
To properly prepare this dish, the yolks of the eggs should be unbroken.
Cook the eggs until they have solidified, yet are still runny.
This should take between 7 and 10 minutes.
For softer eggs, cook for approximately 7 minutes.
For medium eggs, cook for 8½ minutes, and for hard eggs cook for 10 minutes.
Depending on your cooktop, the heat may be uneven.
If the is the case for you, you may need to adjust the position of the skillet while cooking so the eggs heat evenly.
Add olive oil, pepper, Parmesan cheese, and parsley.
When the eggs have reached your desired consistency, remove them from the heat.
Drizzle the olive oil over the eggs.
Then sprinkle them with pepper, Parmesan, and parsley.
Serve the eggs and enjoy.
With a large serving spoon, scoop the eggs and the sauce onto serving plates.
This dish goes well with toast or a firm kind of bread.
Dip the bread into the egg yolk and use it to soak up the sauce.
Frying up Scrambled Eggs Italiano Warm your olive oil in your skillet.
Place your large skillet onto the stovetop and set it to medium heat.
Allow this to heat until the pan and oil are hot.
This should take only a few minutes.
Combine your eggs, basil, and cheese.
Crack your eggs into a mixing bowl.
Then add your basil and cheese to the eggs.
Use a whisk or fork to beat these ingredients together.
You can easily add to this recipe to make double portion by simply doubling these ingredients.
Scramble your eggs in the skillet.
Add the eggs to your skillet.
Use your spatula to push the eggs around so they cook evenly.
It should only take a few minutes for the eggs to solidify and cook completely.
You shouldn't need to adjust your heat at any point in the scrambling process.
Leaving it at medium should cook your eggs sufficiently.
Eat your eggs on garlic bread.
Garlic bread is only a recommendation; these eggs could also be eaten on toast, on peasant bread, or on their own.
Regular bread can be transformed into garlic bread by brushing it with butter and minced garlic.
Finished.
tyn_section: Dutch oven (or a large size, straight-sided skillet)
